customize.text: Tutorial
The Fabled Forbidden Ground: Ochkanatlan

<color=#ffd780>November 12, 2024</color>
Hello, Traveler!
Gaze out from a certain corner of the Flower-Feather Clan and you will be able to make out an ancient city shrouded in a sea of fog.
It is said to be a place where danger lurks around every corner, and from which few intrepid adventurers have ever returned. As such, it has been declared forbidden ground. Little is known of what is truly concealed there, but vague stories are told, and rumors spread in hushed tones...
Ochkanatlan

Many millennia ago, when the first throne of the heavens had not yet appeared in the sky of Teyvat, the world belonged to the dragons. The city that would be called Ochkanatlan in the future was a city of dragons — the
Dragonlord CL-09 "Chronicler of the End Times" Ix Uxul Tz'ib Bolon (Type-L Self-Regulating Overseer Array Integrated Processing Unit), one of the thirteen Dragonlords who became the phlogiston projection, was the sovereign ruler of Chichen Uctokah. This bodiless wisdom, stored in majestic statues, could control all the mechanisms of the city with the help of golden designs and commands. The main core of Chichen Uctokah was the Core of Chu'ulel. When the Python King, Och-Kan, came to power millennia later, he announced the excavation of the ancient ruins in search of the core and met the Dragonlord there. Although she believed him to be the fated Sovereign, he tricked her into imprisoning her in a statue to control the mechanisms of Ochkanatlan, tore her heart apart, and hid it in various places. It was only many years later, when the ruins were discovered by the Traveler and Paimon, that Ixlel's heart, as Paimon called her, was reassembled. The
created before the fires of human civilization had ever been kindled contained all of Ixlel's memories, and it was these memories that bound her within the statue. Her consciousness should have faded within thirty years, but the Dragonlord did not want to die in captivity. Ix Uxul Tz'ib Bolon Ch'ule-L could not destroy herself, but thanks to the heart fragments the Traveler found, she was able to restore the remains of her
and restore her broken heart as a sign of self-protection so as not to violate the sacred law. When the consciousness contained within the statue was finally released and dissipated, all that remained of the ruler of Chichen Uctokah was the Perfect Heart of the Sacred Dragon, which no human gem could compare to.

When Och-Kan failed to use Ix Uxul Tz'ib Bolon Ch'ule-L to control the devices of Ochkanatlan, he decided to create a new Chu'ulel Core that would obey only humans. In order to become a vessel that would rule the entire city, the ruler of the Cinder City sacrificed his own heart, but its desecration led to the destruction of Ochkanatlan. The path to this Core of Chu'ulel is hidden under a fresco depicting the true ruler of Chichen Uctokah. Having come to power, the Python King painted his image over the old one.

Not far from the Core of Chu'ulel is a waterfall where the warrior Quenin had his refuge. 500 years ago, he arrived in Ochkanatlan with a group of adventurers hoping to find a legendary treasure. The warrior died in a collision with the Abyss, but the creature that took his form continued to consider itself Quenin. Quenin's body was left buried under the rocks near the waterfall. For five hundred years, the creature continued to fight monsters until the truth was finally revealed to it.

In the Cradle of Fleeting Dreams lies the throne of the first Pyro Archon. When Xbalanque defeated the dragons thousands of years ago, the first capital of the Pyro Archon was built on the ruins of the dragon civilization, where heaven and earth were separated from one another. Xbalanque borrowed the power of the
here to protect his people from the Abyss and establish the rules of Natlan: the Ode of Resurrection and the Pilgrimage of the Return of the Sacred Flame. Thousands of years later, when the time came for the final battle with the Abyss, the Pyro Archon, Mavuika, used the powers of the divine throne and the gifts of Ronova, the price of which was death. When the Abyss was defeated, Mavuika was ready to repay the debt, asking in return for the restoration of Natlan's Ley Lines from the Lord of the Night, who created the Night Kingdom. Her power would be enough to maintain the Ley Lines for two hundred years, during which time the next Pyro Archon would have to find a new way. She went to the throne of the first Pyro Archon to meet the Ruler of Death and the Lord of the Night and die, but another man approached the Lord of the Night with the same offer, the First of the Eleven Fatui Harbingers and the Sentinel Knight of Khaenri'ah,

500 years ago, during the Khaenri'ahn cataclysm, the Ruler of Death cursed all the people of the kingdom without gods with immortality for the Five Sinners' exploitation of the Abyss. Although most people were innocent and unaware of the Sinners, they were cursed to suffer endless physical torment, cursed to witness the demise of everything they held dear. For five hundred years, Il Capitano had kept the souls of his fallen comrades and the Natlanese in his heart, ready to send them home. The Ley Lines could not accept these souls, but by becoming one with the Lord of the Night, the Sentinel Knight could change the laws that governed the Ley Lines so that the souls could find peace. The Captain gave the Ruler of Death a choice: if he sacrificed his life to the Lord of the Night, Ronova would get the death she desired, but the curse of immortality would negate the very death. Knowing that the curse of immortality could not be lifted and that such a paradox could uproot the natural order of this world, Il Capitano decided to turn the curse into a tool to overturn the oppression of the gods. The Lord of the Night, whose mission was to serve humanity, agreed to the Sentinel Knight's plan and accepted his sacrifice, merging with him. The curse of immortality was not lifted, and Il Capitano remained to sit for eternity on the Throne of the Primal Fire, "frozen" in life and death. For those cursed with immortality, release from the mortal coil was the greatest form of peace, and his path was finally over. Through Il Capitano's sacrifice, the Lord of Night and the Ley Lines of Natlan can exist forever, accepting all souls.
<color=#ffffffd9>"A noble figure coats the sun with frost, and two eras grant salvation to Natlan not once, but twice."</color>

At the Throne of the Primal Fire, the Traveler may offer the Blazing Flint Ore to the Lord of the Night. The first flint lights up the distant past, the land of the journey's beginning, called home. There may be no way back, but when one embraces the night, pure as a mirror it remains, and forever shall it stay. The second flint lights up the juncture of setting forth, the day the journey begins, called farewell. In its departure, the unchanging world betrays people, and yet some try to grasp its shadow. The third flint lights up a daytime of celebration, the moment of open hearts, called friendship. This journey is far from a solitary trial; not only the winds but human hearts too, embrace along the way. The fourth flint lights up a tempestuous night of rain-soaked despair and a sea of anguishing descent called failure. Fighting against the rising tide, a little boat is very nearly submerged; yet, thankfully, it cannot prize the oars from the hands. The fifth flint lights up those days of pushing onward, and the stones with which tall towers are built are called determination. The higher the people climb, the higher and higher they go until at last, they glimpse the destination they have long dreamed of. The sixth flint lights up the moment of arrival and the seats upon which the people may evermore rest, which is called a miracle. Together, one can bring this journey to its conclusion, but instead of an ending, one can see this as a new beginning.

Located at the exit from Ochkanatlan, the Vucub Caquix Tower is where the first meeting of the Traveler and the adventurer Bona took place. Together, they defeated the
went to the legendary Tonatiuh and learned the truth about the treasure hidden on the flying ship. When the evil dragon, who had been attacking people for the past 500 years, was defeated, it fell from a great height and made a hole in the ground, reaching the Night Kingdom itself. There, in the Nursery of Nightmares, the Traveler returned the separated soul to the Python King and said goodbye to him, leaving the ruler of the Cinder City to rest forever.

To the northeast of Ochkanatlan is the Isle of Tozoz, also known as the Isle of Night. Early in Och-Kan's reign, a group of people was sent to the island to keep an eye on the Saurians. It was rumored that those who encountered these pests would fall into the throes of an illness that would grip them day and night, of how the boils that broke forth all over their bodies would be followed by incessant vomiting, before they finally suffered a drastic change in personality and eventually became so frail that they perished. The warriors who could not be saved had wounds on their bodies as if they had been torn to pieces by something sharp. One of the guards who arrived on the island believed that the Saurians should be exterminated and not waste food on them since the only thing they deserved to eat was a good old knuckle sandwich. Over time, the guard came to love the Saurians and realized that they were not "pests" and did not cause festering wounds. Even when the rations were cut, he was not ready to cut back on bird eggs for the hatchlings, who needed extra nutrition to grow. Sometime later, an order came to the Isle of Night to exterminate all Saurians, but the commander of the guards released them all after receiving the notification.

An egg was left on the island, which the guard named Aguara. When the island was attacked by warriors determined to shed blood, he hid in an underground chamber with the egg. His food ran out, and he was gradually losing consciousness, but he could not leave Aguara. Before his death, the guard put the egg into hibernation so that it would not hatch during the attack. Thus, the egg lay in hibernation for over a thousand years until it was found by the Traveler and Paimon. They turned on the incubator for the egg, but even after a long wait, the egg did not change. Deciding that the environment might not be suitable for hatching, the Traveler and Paimon took the egg with them and placed it in the safe abode of their Tepetlisaurus companion. After a long journey in Natlan, a little Tepetlisaurus, Aguara, finally hatched and stayed to live in the Traveler's Serenitea Pot.

There are five furnaces of fiery embers around Ochkanatlan, which supplied the city with energy back in the time of the dragons. When the scarlet-eyed youth rebelled against the ruler of the Cinder City, the first thing they did was to turn off these power sources in order to penetrate the Chu’ulel Core that powered the combustion device. The task of turning off the power sources was entrusted to the craftsman Manqu, who participated in the excavations in Ochkanatlan. Thanks to his help, the officer who served the Python King was able to lead the scarlet-eyed youth to the throne room, where the tyrant of the Cinder City was killed, and the youth became the new Pyro Archon. When the Traveler lit all the furnaces and collected all the golden designs, the old sword in the center of the city, as if tied to space itself, teleported them to the island in the sky, where this sword was finally retrieved.

customize.name: Perfect Heart of the Sacred Dragon
customize.desc:
A flawless piece of jade. Before the fires of human civilization had ever been kindled, it was the heart of the Dragonlord Ix Uxul Tz'ib Bolon Ch'ule-L, ruler of Chichen Uctokah.
It once held the authority to command all devices within Ochkanatlan, the ineffable city, yet can no longer be used due to its energy having been completely exhausted.
Just as with the half-humans who pursued it so relentlessly, the Dragonlord's quest for perfection was ultimately in vain, leading to naught but an end that was as cold and lifeless as jade.

customize.text: Legendary Tonatiuh

In the sky above Ochkanatlan is a flying ship created by the ruler of Cinder City. When Teyvat was still ruled by dragons, they explored the space around their world. In those days, they set up a stairway to reach beyond the skies and were preparing to leave it beyond the orbit and use it to tighten the sky cable and anchor the latter's trajectory. Later, Och-Kan modified it to become Tonatiuh. Once, the Tonatiuh hovering above the clouds was the cherished goal of many adventurers. In the past, many empty dreams failed here, but the path of hope also began here. On the ship, Och-Kan left notes for his compatriots to guide them along the path of the Pyro Archon. The Python King believed that humans could not rely on dragons or heavenly rules. The ancient dragons believed that technology and the power of the Lord of Fire would allow them to rule for ten thousand years, but in the end, they lost their desire for progress and lost everything. Och-Kan wrote that the Vishaps of the Great Volcano once held themselves masters of evolution, but they lost their wisdom in their lengthy, chaotic adaptations, and with it, their power, becoming but beasts to be slaughtered by humans. Their devolution proved that dragon-kind had been abandoned by the evolutionary path, their heirs had lost the primal flame's purity, and the sovereign of fire shall never again be born from amongst them. After the fall of the Vishaps, humanity became the apex life form, the final destination of all things that live in this world. That is why people had to pray only to the true king of humanity, the only real human god, Xbalanque.

Och-Kan's father, Waxaklahun Ubah Kan, did not agree with his son's views. When the race of the Sage of the Stolen Flame was divided by arbitrary divine punishment and they were cut off from their evolutionary paths, the Sage began to seek new possibilities for evolution in the human race. He believed that humanity, created beings, would never be able to comprehend "evolution" because they were only one stage on the path. "Evolution" is a mingled thing, not pure and untainted, and that is why it opposes "eternity." It was on the Tonatiuh that the first personal meeting took place between Waxaklahun Ubah Kan and the Saurian companion of the Traveler, whom the Sage of the Stolen Flame led to Ochkanatlan in various guises.
